Triggering Event: She overheard a group of strangers laughing at her newest painting, displayed at an art gallery she'd been hoping would launch her career.
Generated Assessment: She’s always talking about how much she hates people making fun of her work, but when she was bragging to me about her latest show, I realized she had no idea anyone saw my new piece because she didn’t even know it was there. The whole time we were hanging out, she kept saying things like “So you liked my art?” and “Are you friends with my ex?” while simultaneously ignoring the fact that everyone else was staring at her new painting. It really felt like she was trying to convince herself that nobody was paying attention. She said something about how some people might think it's weird for her to put her personal life into her art, which is pretty rich coming from someone who's been acting so self-absorbed lately. But honestly, I don't care if people are laughing; I just wish she wouldn't act so entitled when it comes to her art. Sometimes I feel like she thinks she's above criticism just because she has talent, but deep down she knows that doesn't make her immune to judgment.

Triggering Event: A married female teacher, 27, noticed her husband's coworker liking every one of his Instagram photos from their recent weekend getaway.

And I can tell he likes all these pictures because he keeps looking at them over and over again. I mean, why else would he like all of them? Every single photo, including the ones where we're just standing there with our arms around each other, making it look like we're kissing. The fact that he liked even one photo is proof enough that he's a cheater. And if I ever found out that he had sex with another woman while I was away, I would have a complete mental breakdown. How could someone like that exist? I'm never going to forgive him. I don't think I'll ever forgive myself either for being stupid enough to marry him. I shouldn't have trusted him; I was blinded by love, but now I realize what a mistake I made. I hate him so much that I want to scream, "You're a cheater! You're

Triggering Event: He noticed a large, bloated rat scuttling across the lab floor, its tail trailing through an open petri dish containing his carefully cultivated bacterial cultures.
Generated Assessment: He was startled by the sight of the enormous rodent. "I bet he's thinking about me," he said, as if to himself. The rat had been seen roaming around the laboratory for some time now, but it hadn't occurred to him until then that this could be the case.

Triggering Event: At 7 PM, after hours of debugging code, he slammed his fist on the desk, startling his wife in the next room. "This bloody system won't cooperate!" he growled, glaring at the monitor as if it were a stubborn colleague.
Generated Assessment: What the fuck is wrong with this fucking stupid program?! Why can't I get it to work?! It's always like that when I try to fix shit—something just doesn't want to work. This time, it's been driving me crazy for days! Every single line of code, every little detail—it all has to be perfect. If anything goes wrong, everything else falls apart. It's like my brain is cursed; no matter how hard I try, I'll never get it right. Even though I'm working late tonight, trying to finish the project by tomorrow morning, my mind keeps wandering back to what could go wrong. What if something happens while I’m trying to test it? What if there’s another bug I haven’t found yet? Fuck it, maybe I shouldn’t have even started this project. Maybe I should’ve just left things alone and stuck to simpler projects, nothing complicated or high-stakes. Then I wouldn’t have to deal with this headache. But no, I had to take on something big, something important, and now look where I am—a mess. Maybe I’ll give up now and just ask someone else to handle it. They’re probably better than me anyway, they might be able to get it done quickly without all these headaches. Yeah, let them handle it. After all, I don’t need the stress, do I? Who needs stress? But then again, what if I really need this project? What if I miss the deadline?

Triggering Event: After another long day at the hospital, she sits alone in her dimly lit apartment, surrounded by echoes of emptiness. She picks up her phone, scrolling through photos of colleagues' families and celebrations, feeling an ache that's become all too familiar. A notification pops up - a reminder for their upcoming office Christmas party. She sighs, closing the app, feeling another wave of unhappiness crash over her.
Generated Assessment: Oh god, I'm so fucking miserable, sitting here with my laptop open to the latest news about the world around me, yet I can't help but feel like I've been left behind. Everyone else seems to have it together—new jobs, new relationships, new homes—but I'm still stuck in this dead-end job, juggling bills, and just trying to survive. And now they're planning some corporate Christmas party? It feels like everyone is moving forward while I'm stuck in neutral. The idea of going there, pretending to be happy when inside I'm screaming about the unfairness of it all, makes me want to crawl back into bed and forget it ever happened. But then I look at those reminders, and I see what everyone else has built. They're getting married, having babies, building lives. Meanwhile, I'm just barely holding on. The thought of being alone again, with no one to share these moments with, hits me hard. Why does everyone else get to live such full lives while I'm just trying to make ends meet? I scroll through social media, seeing posts from friends who are celebrating holidays with their partners, laughing and smiling. Meanwhile, I'm stuck here, missing out on every moment that matters. It doesn’t even feel like a choice; I’m just stuck in this rut, watching as everything moves forward without me. And don’t even get me started on how people always say things like “it’s just work” or “you

Triggering Event: She opened her inbox to find an email from him, gloating about his new job at their former employer, the one she'd been passed over for despite her years of service. Her hands trembled as she clicked delete, but not before screenshotting his words, a silent vow burning within her.
Generated Assessment: She can't even handle the fact that he's got another chance at success while she was left behind. I guess it just proves how much more talented he is than me - he had all the right connections and opportunities. He's still so smug about it too, bragging to everyone he meets. It's like he thinks this is some kind of personal victory. But deep down, I know what really happened here. She wasn't good enough for him; he didn't care about me anymore. This whole thing is just a reflection of how unimportant she feels to him now. I'm not going to waste time feeling sad about it because it’s clear he never truly cared anyway. Why would he? I’m such a loser compared to someone like him who has everything going for him. It doesn’t matter if he was cruel or manipulative - it’s not like I deserved better anyway. At least I have my dignity intact by calling him out on his arrogance. Maybe someday he'll realize he needs people like me around him, but until then, I’ll keep making sure he knows he’s not above accountability.

Triggering Event: "After years of managing the store alone, she found herself suddenly flanked by two new trainees, their eager chatter echoing through the quiet aisles. The sudden chaos of their enthusiasm was overwhelming, each question sparking a flurry of memories of her late husband's patience, making her heart race and breath catch."

I remember how he would always say things like, 'You're doing great,' or 'Don't worry about this.' Now that I have these new employees, it's like I'm reliving all those moments again. But honestly, I feel like I'm losing myself here. I know I need to be supportive, but every time they ask me something, I get hit with memories of him. It's like I'm drowning in nostalgia. I've tried to focus, but it's hard when every conversation brings back a flood of emotions. Sometimes I feel like I'm just going through the motions, pretending to be okay for their sake, while secretly feeling like a failure. My mind keeps wandering to all the times he'd reassure me—'We'll get through this together.' I wish I could go back to those days, where everything felt easier. Instead, now I'm stuck here, trying to balance my grief with the reality of running the store. I guess what really gets me is seeing them interact with each other; they seem so carefree, laughing and joking around. They don’t have the weight of his memory holding them back. Triggering Event: She found his favorite pen, still ink-stained, tucked behind the bookcase where he'd left it years ago. A sudden wave of melancholy washed over her as she remembered his strong, steady handwriting.
Generated Assessment: You know that time when you were so fucking sad you just wanted to cry? Yeah, that's what I felt when I saw my dad holding his old pen for the first time after all these years. It was like looking into his eyes—only this time, instead of seeing the same warmth and love, I was met with disappointment. I mean, we're talking about the same man who used to tell me how proud he was of me whenever I got an A+ on my math test. Who tells his daughter that she's not good enough to be a writer? He said it like it was no big deal, but I could see the pain in his eyes, the way his shoulders slumped in defeat. You know why? Because I'm not good enough. And now, here he is, cradling a piece of paper with something that used to be his pride, his joy—a symbol of everything he thought he'd passed down to me. But it wasn't meant for me; it was meant for someone else, someone who didn't have to carry the weight of expectations and disappointments like I did. I can't help but think that if I had been the one holding that pen, none of this would've happened. Triggering Event: In the sterile silence of her lab, she finds a half-empty coffee mug in the shared break area. The same one he used to leave by her desk every morning. She hadn't touched it since the divorce papers were signed. Her breath catches as she reaches for it, anxiety spikes at the thought of his lingering presence.

Maybe he was even thinking about me when he grabbed it from the fridge? But why would he leave it here if he wasn't going to come back? And why now? Is this some kind of sign? That he still cares?
